FOREWORD
The following is a transcript of an oral interview conducted by the authors of the World Bankâ€™s fiftieth anniversary history: John P. Lewis, Richard Webb and Devesh Kapur, The World Bank: Its First Half Century, Washington, DC: Brookings Institution Press, 1997. It is not a formal oral history, and it is not a systematic overview of the work of the person interviewed. At times the authors discussed the planned publication itself and the sources that should be consulted; at other times they talked about persons and publications extraneous to the Bank. Some interview tapes and transcripts begin and end abruptly. Nevertheless, the World Bank Group Archives believes that this transcript may be of interest to researchers and makes it available for public use.

doc.abstracts: In November 1991, Joseph J. Stern was interviewed on behalf of the World Bank Group Archives oral history program by John Lewis, Richard Webb, and Devesh Kapur. During his tenure at the Bank he worked for the human resource development program (HRDP). He was engaged in programs to teach English, to bring up to snuff on economics and mathematics. He worked on: urban and financial planning which deals with urban loans, water projects, sewer projects, transport issues; program on financial sector training and policies (PFSTP) which deals with capital markets, bank deregulation, project on property tax, trying to help build up a property tax base; a project where the World Bank have been at loggerheads; and on a project in Bank Rakyat, Indonesia BRI, the people's bank on rural savings and rural investment.
